results.title: Early stone tools
results.creator_credit: Clyde B Smith and Extension Media Center, University of California
results.brief_description: Traces the development of stone tools and parallels their development with the evolution of man from austropithecus to homo sapiens. Demonstrates percussion flaking techniques to produce a variety of tools. Shows actual prehistoric tools.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Clyde B Smith and Extension Media Center, University of California

results.title: Early sound films
results.brief_description: Short extracts from the following early sound films which were milestones in the history of Cinema: ‘The Jazz Singer’, ‘The Lights of New York’, ‘On With The Show’, ‘Show of Shows’, ‘In Old Arizona’, ‘All Quiet on the Western Front’.

results.title: Early social behaviour
results.creator_credit: Arnold Gesell, Yale Clinic of Child Development and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Shows the manifestation of the infant personality in a variety of social settings. Ten different children from 8 weeks to 7 years of age are studied and individual differences are emphasised. Also the social significance of the household is conveyed by scenes that reflect parent-child relationships.

results.title: Early Russian cinema. Vol 7: Evgenii Bauer
results.creator_credit: Evegnii Bauer and A Khanzhonov and Co
results.brief_description: Three short silent films by Soviet director Evegnii Bauer that explore themes of class, sexual politics, doomed love, grief and sanity. “A child of the big city” Mary, a seamstress with a meagre existence who dreams of a grander life of luxury and wealth, meets Victor, a well-do-do young man, who spurns his pretentious peers. Beguiled by the luxuries that pepper Victor’s world, Mary becomes flirtatious and develops a taste for decadent habits. Financially ruined and personally demoralised, Victor despairs at Mary’s transformation. This mournful, melancholy melodrama, and morality play, examines the notions of class and corrupting influence of money on character. “The 1102nd ruse” An elderly husband believes himself inured to the skilful wiles of women, to the frustration of his scheming wife. But she is determined to hoodwink him by inventing a cunning ruse unfamiliar to him. A slight comedy of manners that comments on the power of sexuality whilst gently mocking the sanctity of marriage. “Daydreams” A man, mourning the death of his wife, is soon romancing an actress who shares a likeness with his deceased beloved. As his obsession grows, he fears insanity and is beset by ghostly apparitions. All feature musical score, Russian intertitles and English subtitles.

results.title: Early marriage
results.brief_description: Deals with teenage marriage, high school counselling and classroom teaching of marriage preparation. Failures are often due to parents and schools making young marriages difficult, rather than ensuring their success. Discusses types of marriage, religious and civil. Symbolism of the ring and post nuptial ceremonies, which should demonstrate the approval and support of parents and friends.

results.title: Early frost
results.creator_credit: Pierre Pinaud, Isabelle Pragier, Laurent Lavole and Gloria Films
results.brief_description: An endearing story told through the eyes of 10 year old Caroline. Caroline loves her pet rabbit, Pitou, but her parents are ashamed and concerned to learn that Pitou is attracted to rabbits of the same sex. Their resolution to the ‘perceived’ crisis creates turmoil in their relationship with their daughter as Caroline marks out her own revenge and sets the scene for a wonderfully insightful and intelligent lesson to be learnt for her parents.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Pierre Pinaud, Isabelle Pragier, Laurent Lavole and Gloria Films

results.title: Early days yet: a profile of the poet Allen Curnow
results.creator_credit: Shirley Horrocks and Point of View Productions
results.brief_description: This is a beautifully presented documentary about the life and memories of the highly acclaimed New Zealand poet, critic and anthropologist, Allen Curnow. At the age of almost 90, Allen Curnow still wrote poetry using “a ball-point, quantities of A4 paper, and a typewriter”. Charming, gentle and retiring, family man and serious poet, Allen Curnow has won many awards in the world of literature including seven New Zealand Book Awards and the first person outside of Britain to receive the Queen’s Gold Medal for Poetry. The program features Curnow reading several of his poems accompanied by evocative and emotive images to illustrate his writings which often reflect memories of people, places or events from his past. With his quiet sense of humor and reminiscing, and through interviews with his wife Jenny, and fellow poets including Bill Manhire, C.K. Stead, Ian Wedde, Leigh Davis and Elizabeth Smither, Allen Curnow allows us a glimpse into both his personal and his creative life. The documentary takes its title from his latest publication “Early days yet: new and collected poems 1941-1997”. Sadly Allen Curnow passed away on 23 September 2001, three months after completion of this film. Contains archival footage and some scenes in b&w.
